citations.narrative:
Portions of the perimeter fence failed to meet the height requirement and the minimum distance from primary enclosures
requirement, without written approval by the Administrator. Three of the perimeter fence gates measured approximately
five feet high. Two of the gates are located on the southwest portion of the perimeter fencing and serve to contain two fox
enclosures. One gate is located on the north side of the perimeter fence and serves to contain two fishers. Additionally,
the perimeter fence is approximately 20 inches from the fisher enclosure, less than the required 36 inches (three feet).
An insufficient perimeter fence may not effectively act as secondary containment for the animals inside and may allow
unwanted animals or people to enter the facility and potentially harm the animals within.
The perimeter fence must be of sufficient height (at least six feet high) and without gaps to keep regulated animals
contained and unauthorized persons or animals out. It must be of sufficient distance (at least three feet) from the outside
of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons
outside the perimeter fence, or written approval must be obtained from the Administrator.
This is a 1s Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by July 29, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Portions of the perimeter fence failed to meet the height requirement and the minimum distance from primary enclosures 
requirement, without written approval by the Administrator. Three of the perimeter fence gates measured approximately 
five feet high. Two of the gates are located on the southwest portion of the perimeter fencing and serve to contain two fox 
enclosures. One gate is located on the north side of the perimeter fence and serves to contain two fishers. Additionally, 
the perimeter fence is approximately 20 inches from the fisher enclosure, less than the required 36 inches (three feet).  
 
An insufficient perimeter fence may not effectively act as secondary containment for the animals inside and may allow 
unwanted animals or people to enter the facility and potentially harm the animals within.  
 
The perimeter fence must be of sufficient height (at least six feet high) and without gaps to keep regulated animals 
contained and unauthorized persons or animals out. It must be of sufficient distance (at least three feet) from the outside 
of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons 
outside the perimeter fence, or written approval must be obtained from the Administrator. 
 
This is a 1s Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by July 29, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n

species.common: RED FOX (INCLUDES SILVER FOX & CROSS FOX)
